including indicators such as inflation, unemployment, and growth projections.\n    \\item \\emph{Pound Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to fluctuations in the value of the British Pound on the foreign exchange market, indicating whether it is appreciating or depreciating.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to variations in the prices of energy commodities and residential properties.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to the economic impacts of trade relations with foreign countries, particularly those affecting the United Kingdom.\n    \\item \\emph{BoE Expectations, Actions, Assets}: A sentence that discusses the Bank of England’s projections, policy actions, and changes in financial assets such as treasury bonds and bank reserves.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that examines changes in the overall availability of money in the economy, including shifts in loan demand and monetary liquidity.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words, Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific keywords or phrases which clearly indicate a particular monetary policy stance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to shifts in labor market conditions, encompassing changes in productivity, wage trends, and job openings.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Recent economic indicators showing rising inflation and falling unemployment have led the Bank of England to signal a tighter monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BOE is concerned that overheating growth will fuel further inflation, prompting interest rate hikes.\n    \n    \\item ``The acceleration of house prices and energy costs is causing upward pressures on consumer demand, which may necessitate a proactive tightening of monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Rising asset prices and energy costs are seen as signals of mounting inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Falling inflation paired with a rise in unemployment has convinced policymakers at the Bank of England that a more accommodative stance is needed to support the economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation and softer labor market conditions suggest that further easing could help sustain economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Low money supply growth combined with persistently high loan demand has reinforced the BOE's outlook for maintaining an expansionary monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: These factors indicate subdued economic activity, reducing the likelihood of immediate monetary policy tightening.\n\n    \\item ``Total output prices had been flat year on year.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence states that total output prices remained stable and doesn't take a direction on monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The new government had announced its intention to present an updated budget on 8 July.''\\\\\n    \\item \\emph{BoE Expectations, Actions, Assets}: A sentence that discusses the Bank of England’s projections, policy actions, and changes in financial assets such as treasury bonds and bank reserves.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that examines changes in the overall availability of money in the economy, including shifts in loan demand and monetary liquidity.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words, Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific keywords or phrases which clearly indicate a particular monetary policy stance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to shifts in labor market conditions, encompassing changes in productivity, wage trends, and job openings.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Recent economic indicators showing rising inflation and falling unemployment have led the Bank of England to signal a tighter monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BOE is concerned that overheating growth will fuel further inflation, prompting interest rate hikes.\n    \n    \\item ``The acceleration of house prices and energy costs is causing upward pressures on consumer demand, which may necessitate a proactive tightening of monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Rising asset prices and energy costs are seen as signals of mounting inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Falling inflation paired with a rise in unemployment has convinced policymakers at the Bank of England that a more accommodative stance is needed to support the economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation and softer labor market conditions suggest that further easing could help sustain economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Low money supply growth combined with persistently high loan demand has reinforced the BOE's outlook for maintaining an expansionary monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: These factors indicate subdued economic activity, reducing the likelihood of immediate monetary policy tightening.\n\n    \\item ``Total output prices had been flat year on year.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence states that total output prices remained stable and doesn't take a direction on monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The new government had announced its intention to present an updated budget on 8 July.''\\\\\n label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boe}{eight} Economic Status, Pound Value Change, Energy/House Prices, Foreign Nations, BoE Expectations, Actions, Assets, Money Supply, Key Words, Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the overall condition of the economy, including indicators such as inflation, unemployment, and growth projections.\n    \\item \\emph{Pound Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to fluctuations in the value of the British Pound on the foreign exchange market, indicating whether it is appreciating or depreciating.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to variations in the prices of energy commodities and residential properties.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to the economic impacts of trade relations with foreign countries, particularly those affecting the United Kingdom.\n    \\item \\emph{BoE Expectations, Actions, Assets}: A sentence that discusses the Bank of England’s projections, policy actions, and changes in financial assets such as treasury bonds and bank reserves.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that examines changes in the overall availability of money in the economy, including shifts in loan demand and monetary liquidity.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words, Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific keywords or phrases which clearly indicate a particular monetary policy stance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to shifts in labor market conditions, encompassing changes in productivity, wage trends, and job openings.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Recent economic indicators showing rising inflation and falling unemployment have led the Bank of England to signal a tighter monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BOE is concerned that overheating growth will fuel further inflation, prompting interest rate hikes.\n    \n    \\item ``The acceleration of house prices and energy costs is causing upward pressures on consumer demand, which may necessitate a proactive tightening of monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Rising asset prices and energy costs are seen as signals of mounting inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Falling inflation paired with a rise in unemployment has convinced policymakers at the Bank of England that a more accommodative stance is needed to support the economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation and softer labor market conditions suggest that further easing could help sustain economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Low money supply growth combined with persistently high loan demand has reinforced the BOE's outlook for maintaining an expansionary monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: These factors indicate subdued economic activity, reducing the likelihood of immediate monetary policy tightening.\n\n    \\item ``Total output prices had been flat year on year.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence states that total output prices remained stable and doesn't take a direction on monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The new government had announced its intention to present an updated budget on 8 July.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The announcement pertains to a general government schedule and does not contain a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of England}} Status} & Inflation decreases, unemployment increases, low projected growth. & Inflation increases, unemployment decreases, high projected growth, demand outgrows supply. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Pound Value Change} & Pound appreciates. & Pound depreciates. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy andHouse Prices} & Oil/energy prices decrease, house prices decrease. & Oil/energy prices increase, house prices increase. & N/A. & BoE Expectations, Actions, Assets, Money Supply, Key Words, Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the overall condition of the economy, including indicators such as inflation, unemployment, and growth projections.\n    \\item \\emph{Pound Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to fluctuations in the value of the British Pound on the foreign exchange market, indicating whether it is appreciating or depreciating.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to variations in the prices of energy commodities and residential properties.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to the economic impacts of trade relations with foreign countries, particularly those affecting the United Kingdom.\n    \\item \\emph{BoE Expectations, Actions, Assets}: A sentence that discusses the Bank of England’s projections, policy actions, and changes in financial assets such as treasury bonds and bank reserves.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that examines changes in the overall availability of money in the economy, including shifts in loan demand and monetary liquidity.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words, Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific keywords or phrases which clearly indicate a particular monetary policy stance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to shifts in labor market conditions, encompassing changes in productivity, wage trends, and job openings.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Recent economic indicators showing rising inflation and falling unemployment have led the Bank of England to signal a tighter monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BOE is concerned that overheating growth will fuel further inflation, prompting interest rate hikes.\n    \n    \\item ``The acceleration of house prices and energy costs is causing upward pressures on consumer demand, which may necessitate a proactive tightening of monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Rising asset prices and energy costs are seen as signals of mounting inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Falling inflation paired with a rise in unemployment has convinced policymakers at the Bank of England that a more accommodative stance is needed to support the economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation and softer labor market conditions suggest that further easing could help sustain economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Low money supply growth combined with persistently high loan demand has reinforced the BOE's outlook for maintaining an expansionary monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: These factors indicate subdued economic activity, reducing the likelihood of immediate monetary policy tightening.\n\n    \\item ``Total output prices had been flat year on year.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence states that total output prices remained stable and doesn't take a direction on monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The new government had announced its intention to present an updated budget on 8 July.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The announcement pertains to a general government schedule and does not contain a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of England}} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & Inflation decreases, unemployment increases, low projected growth. & Inflation increases, unemployment decreases, high projected growth, demand outgrows supply. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Pound Value Change} & Pound appreciates. & Pound depreciates. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy andHouse Prices} & Oil/energy prices decrease, house prices decrease. & Oil/energy prices increase, house prices increase. & N/A. & not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BoE Expectations, Actions, Assets} & Expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury residential properties.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to the economic impacts of trade relations with foreign countries, particularly those affecting the United Kingdom.\n    \\item \\emph{BoE Expectations, Actions, Assets}: A sentence that discusses the Bank of England’s projections, policy actions, and changes in financial assets such as treasury bonds and bank reserves.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that examines changes in the overall availability of money in the economy, including shifts in loan demand and monetary liquidity.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words, Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific keywords or phrases which clearly indicate a particular monetary policy stance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to shifts in labor market conditions, encompassing changes in productivity, wage trends, and job openings.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Recent economic indicators showing rising inflation and falling unemployment have led the Bank of England to signal a tighter monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BOE is concerned that overheating growth will fuel further inflation, prompting interest rate hikes.\n    \n    \\item ``The acceleration of house prices and energy costs is causing upward pressures on consumer demand, which may necessitate a proactive tightening of monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Rising asset prices and energy costs are seen as signals of mounting inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Falling inflation paired with a rise in unemployment has convinced policymakers at the Bank of England that a more accommodative stance is needed to support the economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation and softer labor market conditions suggest that further easing could help sustain economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Low money supply growth combined with persistently high loan demand has reinforced the BOE's outlook for maintaining an expansionary monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: These factors indicate subdued economic activity, reducing the likelihood of immediate monetary policy tightening.\n\n    \\item ``Total output prices had been flat year on year.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence states that total output prices remained stable and doesn't take a direction on monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The new government had announced its intention to present an updated budget on 8 July.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The announcement pertains to a general government schedule and does not contain a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of England}} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & Inflation decreases, unemployment increases, low projected growth. & Inflation increases, unemployment decreases, high projected growth, demand outgrows supply. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Pound Value Change} & Pound appreciates. & Pound depreciates. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy andHouse Prices} & Oil/energy prices decrease, house prices decrease. & Oil/energy prices increase, house prices increase. & N/A. & shifts in labor market conditions, encompassing changes in productivity, wage trends, and job openings.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Recent economic indicators showing rising inflation and falling unemployment have led the Bank of England to signal a tighter monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BOE is concerned that overheating growth will fuel further inflation, prompting interest rate hikes.\n    \n    \\item ``The acceleration of house prices and energy costs is causing upward pressures on consumer demand, which may necessitate a proactive tightening of monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Rising asset prices and energy costs are seen as signals of mounting inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Falling inflation paired with a rise in unemployment has convinced policymakers at the Bank of England that a more accommodative stance is needed to support the economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation and softer labor market conditions suggest that further easing could help sustain economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Low money supply growth combined with persistently high loan demand has reinforced the BOE's outlook for maintaining an expansionary monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: These factors indicate subdued economic activity, reducing the likelihood of immediate monetary policy tightening.\n\n    \\item ``Total output prices had been flat year on year.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence states that total output prices remained stable and doesn't take a direction on monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The new government had announced its intention to present an updated budget on 8 July.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The announcement pertains to a general government schedule and does not contain a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of England}} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & Inflation decreases, unemployment increases, low projected growth. & Inflation increases, unemployment decreases, high projected growth, demand outgrows supply. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Pound Value Change} & Pound appreciates. & Pound depreciates. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy andHouse Prices} & Oil/energy prices decrease, house prices decrease. & Oil/energy prices increase, house prices increase. & N/A. & which may necessitate a proactive tightening of monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Rising asset prices and energy costs are seen as signals of mounting inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Falling inflation paired with a rise in unemployment has convinced policymakers at the Bank of England that a more accommodative stance is needed to support the economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation and softer labor market conditions suggest that further easing could help sustain economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Low money supply growth combined with persistently high loan demand has reinforced the BOE's outlook for maintaining an expansionary monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: These factors indicate subdued economic activity, reducing the likelihood of immediate monetary policy tightening.\n\n    \\item ``Total output prices had been flat year on year.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence states that total output prices remained stable and doesn't take a direction on monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The new government had announced its intention to present an updated budget on 8 July.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The announcement pertains to a general government schedule and does not contain a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of England}}     \n\\label{tb:boe_mp_stance_guide}\n\\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & Inflation decreases, unemployment increases, low projected growth. & Inflation increases, unemployment decreases, high projected growth, demand outgrows supply. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Pound Value Change} & Pound appreciates. & Pound depreciates. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy andHouse Prices} & Oil/energy prices decrease, house prices decrease. & Oil/energy prices increase, house prices increase. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & UK trade deficit decreases. & UK trade deficit increases. & Relating to foreign economic policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BoE Expectations, Actions, Assets} & Expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury reducing the likelihood of immediate monetary policy tightening.\n\n    \\item ``Total output prices had been flat year on year.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence states that total output prices remained stable and doesn't take a direction on monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The new government had announced its intention to present an updated budget on 8 July.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The announcement pertains to a general government schedule and does not contain a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of England}} growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Pound Value Change} & Pound appreciates. & Pound depreciates. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy andHouse Prices} & Oil/energy prices decrease, house prices decrease. & Oil/energy prices increase, house prices increase. & N/A. & reserves.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that examines changes in the overall availability of money in the economy, including shifts in loan demand and monetary liquidity.\n    \\item reserves.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that examines changes in the overall availability of money in the economy, including shifts in loan demand and monetary liquidity.\n    \\item BoE Expectations, Actions, Assets, Money Supply, Key Words, Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the overall condition of the economy, including indicators such as inflation, unemployment, and growth projections.\n    \\item \\emph{Pound Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to fluctuations in the value of the British Pound on the foreign exchange market, indicating whether it is appreciating or depreciating.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to variations in the prices of energy commodities and residential properties.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to the economic impacts of trade relations with foreign countries, particularly those affecting the United Kingdom.\n    \\item \\emph{BoE Expectations, Actions, Assets}: A sentence that discusses the Bank of England’s projections, policy actions, and changes in financial assets such as treasury bonds and bank reserves.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that examines changes in the overall availability of money in the economy, including shifts in loan demand and monetary liquidity.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words, Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific keywords or phrases which clearly indicate a particular monetary policy stance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to shifts in labor market conditions, encompassing changes in productivity, wage trends, and job openings.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Recent economic indicators showing rising inflation and falling unemployment have led the Bank of England to signal a tighter monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BOE is concerned that overheating growth will fuel further inflation, prompting interest rate hikes.\n    \n    \\item ``The acceleration of house prices and energy costs is causing upward pressures on consumer demand, which may necessitate a proactive tightening of monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Rising asset prices and energy costs are seen as signals of mounting inflationary pressures.\n    \n persistently high loan demand has reinforced the BOE's outlook for maintaining an expansionary monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: These factors indicate subdued economic activity, reducing the likelihood of immediate monetary policy tightening.\n\n    \\item ``Total output prices had been flat year on year.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence states that total output prices remained stable and doesn't take a direction on monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The new government had announced its intention to present an updated budget on 8 July.''\\\\\n BoE Expectations, Actions, Assets, Money Supply, Key Words, Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the overall condition of the economy, including indicators such as inflation, unemployment, and growth projections.\n    \\item \\emph{Pound Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to fluctuations in the value of the British Pound on the foreign exchange market, indicating whether it is appreciating or depreciating.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to variations in the prices of energy commodities and residential properties.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to the economic impacts of trade relations with foreign countries, particularly those affecting the United Kingdom.\n    \\item \\emph{BoE Expectations, Actions, Assets}: A sentence that discusses the Bank of England’s projections, policy actions, and changes in financial assets such as treasury bonds and bank reserves.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that examines changes in the overall availability of money in the economy, including shifts in loan demand and monetary liquidity.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words, Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific keywords or phrases which clearly indicate a particular monetary policy stance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to shifts in labor market conditions, encompassing changes in productivity, wage trends, and job openings.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Recent economic indicators showing rising inflation and falling unemployment have led the Bank of England to signal a tighter monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BOE is concerned that overheating growth will fuel further inflation, prompting interest rate hikes.\n    \n    \\item ``The acceleration of house prices and energy costs is causing upward pressures on consumer demand, which may necessitate a proactive tightening of monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Rising asset prices and energy costs are seen as signals of mounting inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Falling inflation paired with a rise in unemployment has convinced policymakers at the Bank of England that a more accommodative stance is needed to support the economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation and softer labor market conditions suggest that further easing could help sustain economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Low money supply growth combined with persistently high loan demand has reinforced the BOE's outlook for maintaining an expansionary monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: These factors indicate subdued economic activity, reducing the likelihood of immediate monetary policy tightening.\n\n    \\item ``Total output prices had been flat year on year.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence states that total output prices remained stable and doesn't take a direction on monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The new government had announced its intention to present an updated budget on 8 July.''\\\\\n is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy andHouse Prices} & Oil/energy prices decrease, house prices decrease. & Oil/energy prices increase, house prices increase. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & UK trade deficit decreases. & UK trade deficit increases. & Relating to foreign economic policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BoE Expectations, Actions, Assets} & Expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury foreign exchange market, indicating whether it is appreciating or depreciating.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to variations in the prices of energy commodities and residential properties.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to the economic impacts of trade relations with foreign countries, particularly those affecting the United Kingdom.\n    \\item \\emph{BoE Expectations, Actions, Assets}: A sentence that discusses the Bank of England’s projections, policy actions, and changes in financial assets such as treasury bonds and bank reserves.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that examines changes in the overall availability of money in the economy, including shifts in loan demand and monetary liquidity.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words, Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific keywords or phrases which clearly indicate a particular monetary policy stance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to shifts in labor market conditions, encompassing changes in productivity, wage trends, and job openings.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Recent economic indicators showing rising inflation and falling unemployment have led the Bank of England to signal a tighter monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BOE is concerned that overheating growth will fuel further inflation, prompting interest rate hikes.\n    \n    \\item ``The acceleration of house prices and energy costs is causing upward pressures on consumer demand, which may necessitate a proactive tightening of monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Rising asset prices and energy costs are seen as signals of mounting inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Falling inflation paired with a rise in unemployment has convinced policymakers at the Bank of England that a more accommodative stance is needed to support the economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation and softer labor market conditions suggest that further easing could help sustain economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Low money supply growth combined with persistently high loan demand has reinforced the BOE's outlook for maintaining an expansionary monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: These factors indicate subdued economic activity, reducing the likelihood of immediate monetary policy tightening.\n\n    \\item ``Total output prices had been flat year on year.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence states that total output residential properties.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to the economic impacts of trade relations with foreign countries, particularly those affecting the United Kingdom.\n    \\item \\emph{BoE Expectations, Actions, Assets}: A sentence that discusses the Bank of England’s projections, policy actions, and changes in financial assets such as treasury bonds and bank reserves.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that examines changes in the overall availability of money in the economy, including shifts in loan demand and monetary liquidity.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words, Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific keywords or phrases which clearly indicate a particular monetary policy stance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to shifts in labor market conditions, encompassing changes in productivity, wage trends, and job openings.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Recent economic indicators showing rising inflation and falling unemployment have led the Bank of England to signal a tighter monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BOE is concerned that overheating growth will fuel further inflation, prompting interest rate hikes.\n    \n    \\item ``The acceleration of house prices and energy costs is causing upward pressures on consumer demand, which may necessitate a proactive tightening of monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Rising asset prices and energy costs are seen as signals of mounting inflationary pressures.\n    \n including indicators such as inflation, unemployment, and growth projections.\n    \\item \\emph{Pound Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to fluctuations in the value of the British Pound on the foreign exchange market, indicating whether it is appreciating or depreciating.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to variations in the prices of energy commodities and residential properties.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to the economic impacts of trade relations with foreign countries, particularly those affecting the United Kingdom.\n    \\item \\emph{BoE Expectations, Actions, Assets}: A sentence that discusses the Bank of England’s projections, policy actions, and changes in financial assets such as treasury bonds and bank reserves.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that examines changes in the overall availability of money in the economy, including shifts in loan demand and monetary liquidity.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words, Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific keywords or phrases which clearly indicate a particular monetary policy stance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to shifts in labor market conditions, encompassing changes in productivity, wage trends, and job openings.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Recent economic indicators showing rising inflation and falling unemployment have led the Bank of England to signal a tighter monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BOE is concerned that overheating growth will fuel further inflation, prompting interest rate hikes.\n    \n    \\item ``The acceleration of house prices and energy costs is causing upward pressures on consumer demand, which may necessitate a proactive tightening of monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Rising asset prices and energy costs are seen as signals of mounting inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Falling inflation paired with a rise in unemployment has convinced policymakers at the Bank of England that a more accommodative stance is needed to support the economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation and softer labor market conditions suggest that further easing could help sustain economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Low money supply growth combined with persistently high loan demand has reinforced the BOE's outlook for maintaining an expansionary monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: These factors indicate subdued economic activity, reducing the likelihood of immediate monetary policy tightening.\n\n    \\item ``Total output prices had been flat year on year.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence states that total output prices remained stable and doesn't take a direction on monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The new government had announced its intention to present an updated budget on 8 July.''\\\\\n reserves.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that examines changes in the overall availability of money in the economy, including shifts in loan demand and monetary liquidity.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words, Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific keywords or phrases which clearly indicate a particular monetary policy stance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to shifts in labor market conditions, encompassing changes in productivity, wage trends, and job openings.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Recent economic indicators showing rising inflation and falling unemployment have led the Bank of England to signal a tighter monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BOE is concerned that overheating growth will fuel further inflation, prompting interest rate hikes.\n    \n    \\item ``The acceleration of house prices and energy costs is causing upward pressures on consumer demand, which may necessitate a proactive tightening of monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Rising asset prices and energy costs are seen as signals of mounting inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Falling inflation paired with a rise in unemployment has convinced policymakers at the Bank of England that a more accommodative stance is needed to support the economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation and softer labor market conditions suggest that further easing could help sustain economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Low money supply growth combined with persistently high loan demand has reinforced the BOE's outlook for maintaining an expansionary monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: These factors indicate subdued economic activity,    \\item \\emph{BoE Expectations, Actions, Assets}: A sentence that discusses the Bank of England’s projections, policy actions, and changes in financial assets such as treasury bonds and bank reserves.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that examines changes in the overall availability of money in the economy, including shifts in loan demand and monetary liquidity.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words, Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific keywords or phrases which clearly indicate a particular monetary policy stance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to shifts in labor market conditions, encompassing changes in productivity, wage trends, and job openings.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Recent economic indicators showing rising inflation and falling unemployment have led the Bank of England to signal a tighter monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BOE is concerned that overheating growth will fuel further inflation, prompting interest rate hikes.\n    \n    \\item ``The acceleration of house prices and energy costs is causing upward pressures on consumer demand, which may necessitate a proactive tightening of monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Rising asset prices and energy costs are seen as signals of mounting inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Falling inflation paired with a rise in unemployment has convinced policymakers at the Bank of England that a more accommodative stance is needed to support the economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation and softer labor market conditions suggest that further easing could help sustain economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Low money supply growth combined with persistently high loan demand has reinforced the BOE's outlook for maintaining an expansionary monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: These factors indicate subdued economic activity, reducing the likelihood of immediate monetary policy tightening.\n\n    \\item ``Total output prices had been flat year on year.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence states that total output prices remained stable and doesn't take a direction on monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The new government had announced its intention to present an updated budget on 8 July.''\\\\\n \\emph{Key Words, Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific keywords or phrases which clearly indicate a particular monetary policy stance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to shifts in labor market conditions, encompassing changes in productivity, wage trends, and job openings.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Recent economic indicators showing rising inflation and falling unemployment have led the Bank of England to signal a tighter monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BOE is concerned that overheating growth will fuel further inflation, prompting interest rate hikes.\n    \n    \\item ``The acceleration of house prices and energy costs is causing upward pressures on consumer demand, which may necessitate a proactive tightening of monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Rising asset prices and energy costs are seen as signals of mounting inflationary pressures.\n    \n \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation and softer labor market conditions suggest that further easing could help sustain economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Low money supply growth combined with persistently high loan demand has reinforced the BOE's outlook for maintaining an expansionary monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: These factors indicate subdued economic activity, reducing the likelihood of immediate monetary policy tightening.\n\n    \\item ``Total output prices had been flat year on year.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence states that total output Your output must follow this structure:\n            {\n            "label": "hawkish | dovish | neutral | irrelevant",\n            "justification": "One-sentence explanation for the assigned label"\n            }'}, {'role': 'user', 'content': "Input:\n\n                ### Annotation Guide: \\mptext{boe}{eight} Economic Status, Pound Value Change, Energy/House Prices, Foreign Nations, BoE Expectations, Actions, Assets, Money Supply, Key Words, Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the overall condition of the economy, including indicators such as inflation, unemployment, and growth projections.\n    \\item \\emph{Pound Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to fluctuations in the value of the British Pound on the foreign exchange market, indicating whether it is appreciating or depreciating.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to variations in the prices of energy commodities and residential properties.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to the economic impacts of trade relations with foreign countries, particularly those affecting the United Kingdom.\n    \\item \\emph{BoE Expectations, Actions, Assets}: A sentence that discusses the Bank of England’s projections, policy actions, and changes in financial assets such as treasury bonds and bank reserves.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that examines changes in the overall availability of money in the economy, including shifts in loan demand and monetary liquidity.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words, Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific keywords or phrases which clearly indicate a particular monetary policy stance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to shifts in labor market conditions, encompassing changes in productivity, wage trends, and job openings.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Recent economic indicators showing rising inflation and falling unemployment have led the Bank of England to signal a tighter monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BOE is concerned that overheating growth will fuel further inflation, prompting interest rate hikes.\n    \n    \\item ``The acceleration of house prices and energy costs is causing upward pressures on consumer demand, which may necessitate a proactive tightening of monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Rising asset prices and energy costs are seen as signals of mounting inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Falling inflation paired with a rise in unemployment has convinced policymakers at the Bank of England that a more accommodative stance is needed to support the economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation and softer labor market conditions suggest that further easing could help sustain economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Low money supply growth combined with persistently high loan demand has reinforced the BOE's outlook for maintaining an expansionary monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: These factors indicate subdued economic activity, reducing the likelihood of immediate monetary policy tightening.\n\n    \\item ``Total output prices had been flat year on year.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence states that total output prices remained stable and doesn't take a direction on monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The new government had announced its intention to present an updated budget on 8 July.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The announcement pertains to a general government schedule and does not contain a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of England}}     \n\\label{tb:boe_mp_stance_guide}\n\\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & Inflation decreases, unemployment increases, low projected growth. & Inflation increases, unemployment decreases, high projected growth, demand outgrows supply. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Pound Value Change} & Pound appreciates. & Pound depreciates. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy andHouse Prices} & Oil/energy prices decrease, house prices decrease. & Oil/energy prices increase, house prices increase. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & UK trade deficit decreases. & UK trade deficit increases. & Relating to foreign economic policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BoE Expectations, Actions, Assets} & Expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury security yields, and reduction of bank reserves. & Expects high inflation, widening spreads of treasury bonds, increase in treasury security yields, increase in TIPS value, increase bank reserves. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Money Supply} & Low money supply, slow M4 growth, increased loan demand. & High money supply, increased demand for goods, low loan demand. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Key Words and Phrases} & Stance is ``accommodative,'' indicating a focus on ``maximum employment'' and ``price stability.'' & Indicative a focus on ``price stability'' and ``sustained growth.'' & Usage of ``mixed,'' ``moderate,'' ``reaffirmed.'' & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Labor} & Productivity increases, unemployment decreases, wages increase, job openings increase. & Productivity decreases, unemployment increases, wages decrease, job openings decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: the prospective increase in vat in january 2011 would affect measured cpi inflation for twelve months, and would probably keep inflation above the target for a period.\n                "}]

including indicators such as inflation, unemployment, and growth projections.\n    \\item \\emph{Pound Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to fluctuations in the value of the British Pound on the foreign exchange market, indicating whether it is appreciating or depreciating.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to variations in the prices of energy commodities and residential properties.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to the economic impacts of trade relations with foreign countries, particularly those affecting the United Kingdom.\n    \\item \\emph{BoE Expectations, Actions, Assets}: A sentence that discusses the Bank of England’s projections, policy actions, and changes in financial assets such as treasury bonds and bank reserves.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that examines changes in the overall availability of money in the economy, including shifts in loan demand and monetary liquidity.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words, Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific keywords or phrases which clearly indicate a particular monetary policy stance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to shifts in labor market conditions, encompassing changes in productivity, wage trends, and job openings.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Recent economic indicators showing rising inflation and falling unemployment have led the Bank of England to signal a tighter monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BOE is concerned that overheating growth will fuel further inflation, prompting interest rate hikes.\n    \n    \\item ``The acceleration of house prices and energy costs is causing upward pressures on consumer demand, which may necessitate a proactive tightening of monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Rising asset prices and energy costs are seen as signals of mounting inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Falling inflation paired with a rise in unemployment has convinced policymakers at the Bank of England that a more accommodative stance is needed to support the economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation and softer labor market conditions suggest that further easing could help sustain economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Low money supply growth combined with persistently high loan demand has reinforced the BOE's outlook for maintaining an expansionary monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: These factors indicate subdued economic activity, reducing the likelihood of immediate monetary policy tightening.\n\n    \\item ``Total output prices had been flat year on year.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence states that total output prices remained stable and doesn't take a direction on monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The new government had announced its intention to present an updated budget on 8 July.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The announcement pertains to a general government schedule and does not contain a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of England}} reserves.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that examines changes in the overall availability of money in the economy, including shifts in loan demand and monetary liquidity.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words, Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific keywords or phrases which clearly indicate a particular monetary policy stance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to shifts in labor market conditions, encompassing changes in productivity, wage trends, and job openings.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Recent economic indicators showing rising inflation and falling unemployment have led the Bank of England to signal a tighter monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BOE is concerned that overheating growth will fuel further inflation, prompting interest rate hikes.\n    \n    \\item ``The acceleration of house prices and energy costs is causing upward pressures on consumer demand, which may necessitate a proactive tightening of monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Rising asset prices and energy costs are seen as signals of mounting inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Falling inflation paired with a rise in unemployment has convinced policymakers at the Bank of England that a more accommodative stance is needed to support the economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation and softer labor market conditions suggest that further easing could help sustain economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Low money supply growth combined with persistently high loan demand has reinforced the BOE's outlook for maintaining an expansionary monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: These factors indicate subdued economic activity, reducing the likelihood of immediate monetary policy tightening.\n\n    \\item ``Total output prices had been flat year on year.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence states that total output prices remained stable and doesn't take a direction on monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The new government had announced its intention to present an updated budget on 8 July.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The announcement pertains to a general government schedule and does not contain a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of England}} growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Pound Value Change} & Pound appreciates. & Pound depreciates. & N/A. & Sentence indicators showing rising inflation and falling unemployment have led the Bank of England to signal a tighter monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BOE is concerned that overheating growth will fuel further inflation, prompting interest rate hikes.\n    \n    \\item ``The acceleration of house prices and energy costs is causing upward pressures on consumer demand, which may necessitate a proactive tightening of monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Rising asset prices and energy costs are seen as signals of mounting inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Falling inflation paired with a rise in unemployment has convinced policymakers at the Bank of England that a more accommodative stance is needed to support the economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation and softer labor market conditions suggest that further easing could help sustain economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Low money supply growth combined with persistently high loan demand has reinforced the BOE's outlook for maintaining an expansionary monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: These factors indicate subdued economic activity, reducing the likelihood of immediate monetary policy tightening.\n\n    \\item ``Total output prices had been flat year on year.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence states that total output prices remained stable and doesn't take a direction on monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The new government had announced its intention to present an updated budget on 8 July.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The announcement pertains to a general government schedule and does not contain a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of England}}     \n\\label{tb:boe_mp_stance_guide}\n\\\\\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endfirsthead\n\n\\toprule\n\\textbf{Category} & \\textbf{Dovish} & \\textbf{Hawkish} & \\textbf{Neutral} & \\textbf{Irrelevant} \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\endhead\n\n\\textbf{Economic Status} & Inflation decreases, unemployment increases, low projected growth. & Inflation increases, unemployment decreases, high projected growth, demand outgrows supply. & When unemployment rate or growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Pound Value Change} & Pound appreciates. & Pound depreciates. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy andHouse Prices} & Oil/energy prices decrease, house prices decrease. & Oil/energy prices increase, house prices increase. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Foreign Nations} & UK trade deficit decreases. & UK trade deficit increases. & Relating to foreign economic policy. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{BoE Expectations, Actions, Assets} & Expects subpar inflation, disinflation, narrowing spreads of treasury bonds, decreases in treasury decrease. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\bottomrule\n\\end{longtable}\n\n\n\n\n                ### Sentence: at this meeting, the committee voted to maintain bank rate \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation and softer labor market conditions suggest that further easing could help sustain economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Low money supply growth combined with persistently high loan demand has reinforced the BOE's outlook for maintaining an expansionary monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: These factors indicate subdued economic activity, reducing the likelihood of immediate monetary policy tightening.\n\n    \\item ``Total output prices had been flat year on year.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence states that total output prices remained stable and doesn't take a direction on monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The new government had announced its intention to present an updated budget on 8 July.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Irrelevant}: The announcement pertains to a general government schedule and does not contain a monetary policy stance.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\newpage\n\\begin{longtable}{p{0.118\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}p{0.183\\textwidth}}\n\\caption{\\mptitle{Bank of England}} reserves.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that examines changes in the overall availability of money in the economy, including shifts in loan demand and monetary liquidity.\n    \\item shifts in labor market conditions, encompassing changes in productivity, wage trends, and job openings.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Recent economic BoE Expectations, Actions, Assets, Money Supply, Key Words, Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the overall condition of the economy, including indicators such as inflation, unemployment, and growth projections.\n    \\item \\emph{Pound Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to fluctuations in the value of the British Pound on the foreign exchange market, indicating whether it is appreciating or depreciating.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to variations in the prices of energy commodities and residential properties.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to the economic impacts of trade relations with foreign countries, particularly those affecting the United Kingdom.\n    \\item \\emph{BoE Expectations, Actions, Assets}: A sentence that discusses the Bank of England’s projections, policy actions, and changes in financial assets such as treasury bonds and bank reserves.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that examines changes in the overall availability of money in the economy, including shifts in loan demand and monetary liquidity.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words, Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific keywords or phrases which clearly indicate a particular monetary policy stance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to shifts in labor market conditions, encompassing changes in productivity, wage trends, and job openings.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Recent economic indicators showing rising inflation and falling unemployment have led the Bank of England to signal a tighter monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BOE is concerned that overheating growth will fuel further inflation, prompting interest rate hikes.\n    \n    \\item ``The acceleration of house prices and energy costs is causing upward pressures on consumer demand, which may necessitate a proactive tightening of monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Rising asset prices and energy costs are seen as signals of mounting inflationary pressures.\n    \n persistently high loan demand has reinforced the BOE's outlook for maintaining an expansionary monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: These factors indicate subdued economic activity, reducing the likelihood of immediate monetary policy tightening.\n\n    \\item ``Total output prices had been flat year on year.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence states that total output growth is unchanged, maintained, or sustained. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Pound Value Change} & Pound appreciates. & Pound depreciates. & N/A. & Sentence is not relevant to monetary policy. \\\\\n\\midrule\n\\textbf{Energy andHouse Prices} & Oil/energy prices decrease, house prices decrease. & Oil/energy prices increase, house prices increase. & N/A. & BoE Expectations, Actions, Assets, Money Supply, Key Words, Phrases, and Labor.\n\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item \\emph{Economic Status}: A sentence pertaining to the overall condition of the economy, including indicators such as inflation, unemployment, and growth projections.\n    \\item \\emph{Pound Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to fluctuations in the value of the British Pound on the foreign exchange market, indicating whether it is appreciating or depreciating.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to variations in the prices of energy commodities and residential properties.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to the economic impacts of trade relations with foreign countries, particularly those affecting the United Kingdom.\n    \\item \\emph{BoE Expectations, Actions, Assets}: A sentence that discusses the Bank of England’s projections, policy actions, and changes in financial assets such as treasury bonds and bank reserves.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that examines changes in the overall availability of money in the economy, including shifts in loan demand and monetary liquidity.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words, Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific keywords or phrases which clearly indicate a particular monetary policy stance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to shifts in labor market conditions, encompassing changes in productivity, wage trends, and job openings.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Recent economic indicators showing rising inflation and falling unemployment have led the Bank of England to signal a tighter monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BOE is concerned that overheating growth will fuel further inflation, prompting interest rate hikes.\n    \n    \\item ``The acceleration of house prices and energy costs is causing upward pressures on consumer demand, which may necessitate a proactive tightening of monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Rising asset prices and energy costs are seen as signals of mounting inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Falling inflation paired with a rise in unemployment has convinced policymakers at the Bank of England that a more accommodative stance is needed to support the economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation and softer labor market conditions suggest that further easing could help sustain economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Low money supply growth combined with persistently high loan demand has reinforced the BOE's outlook for maintaining an expansionary monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: These factors indicate subdued economic activity, reducing the likelihood of immediate monetary policy tightening.\n\n    \\item ``Total output prices had been flat year on year.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence states that total output prices remained stable and doesn't take a direction on monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The new government had announced its intention to present an updated budget on 8 July.''\\\\\n including indicators such as inflation, unemployment, and growth projections.\n    \\item \\emph{Pound Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to fluctuations in the value of the British Pound on the foreign exchange market, indicating whether it is appreciating or depreciating.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to variations in the prices of energy commodities and residential properties.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to the economic impacts of trade relations with foreign countries, particularly those affecting the United Kingdom.\n    \\item \\emph{BoE Expectations, Actions, Assets}: A sentence that discusses the Bank of England’s projections, policy actions, and changes in financial assets such as treasury bonds and bank reserves.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that examines changes in the overall availability of money in the economy, including shifts in loan demand and monetary liquidity.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words, Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific keywords or phrases which clearly indicate a particular monetary policy stance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to shifts in labor market conditions, encompassing changes in productivity, wage trends, and job openings.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Recent economic indicators showing rising inflation and falling unemployment have led the Bank of England to signal a tighter monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BOE is concerned that overheating growth will fuel further inflation, prompting interest rate hikes.\n    \n    \\item ``The acceleration of house prices and energy costs is causing upward pressures on consumer demand, which may necessitate a proactive tightening of monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Rising asset prices and energy costs are seen as signals of mounting inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Falling inflation paired with a rise in unemployment has convinced policymakers at the Bank of England that a more accommodative stance is needed to support the economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation and softer labor market conditions suggest that further easing could help sustain economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Low money supply growth combined with persistently high loan demand has reinforced the BOE's outlook for maintaining an expansionary monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: These factors indicate subdued economic activity, reducing the likelihood of immediate monetary policy tightening.\n\n    \\item ``Total output prices had been flat year on year.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence states that total output prices remained stable and doesn't take a direction on monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The new government had announced its intention to present an updated budget on 8 July.''\\\\\n reserves.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that examines changes in the overall availability of money in the economy, including shifts in loan demand and monetary liquidity.\n    \\item shifts in labor market conditions, encompassing changes in productivity, wage trends, and job openings.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Recent economic overheating growth will fuel further inflation, prompting interest rate hikes.\n    \n    \\item ``The acceleration of house prices and energy costs is causing upward pressures on consumer demand, which may necessitate a proactive tightening of monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Rising asset prices and energy costs are seen as signals of mounting inflationary pressures.\n    \n including indicators such as inflation, unemployment, and growth projections.\n    \\item \\emph{Pound Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to fluctuations in the value of the British Pound on the foreign exchange market, indicating whether it is appreciating or depreciating.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to variations in the prices of energy commodities and residential properties.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to the economic impacts of trade relations with foreign countries, particularly those affecting the United Kingdom.\n    \\item \\emph{BoE Expectations, Actions, Assets}: A sentence that discusses the Bank of England’s projections, policy actions, and changes in financial assets such as treasury bonds and bank reserves.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that examines changes in the overall availability of money in the economy, including shifts in loan demand and monetary liquidity.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words, Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific keywords or phrases which clearly indicate a particular monetary policy stance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to shifts in labor market conditions, encompassing changes in productivity, wage trends, and job openings.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Recent economic indicators showing rising inflation and falling unemployment have led the Bank of England to signal a tighter monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BOE is concerned that overheating growth will fuel further inflation, prompting interest rate hikes.\n    \n    \\item ``The acceleration of house prices and energy costs is causing upward pressures on consumer demand, which may necessitate a proactive tightening of monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Rising asset prices and energy costs are seen as signals of mounting inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Falling inflation paired with a rise in unemployment has convinced policymakers at the Bank of England that a more accommodative stance is needed to support the economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation and softer labor market conditions suggest that further easing could help sustain economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Low money supply growth combined with persistently high loan demand has reinforced the BOE's outlook for maintaining an expansionary monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: These factors indicate subdued economic activity, reducing the likelihood of immediate monetary policy tightening.\n\n    \\item ``Total output prices had been flat year on year.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence states that total output prices remained stable and doesn't take a direction on monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The new government had announced its intention to present an updated budget on 8 July.''\\\\\n including indicators such as inflation, unemployment, and growth projections.\n    \\item \\emph{Pound Value Change}: A sentence pertaining to fluctuations in the value of the British Pound on the foreign exchange market, indicating whether it is appreciating or depreciating.\n    \\item \\emph{Energy/House Prices}: A sentence pertaining to variations in the prices of energy commodities and residential properties.\n    \\item \\emph{Foreign Nations}: A sentence pertaining to the economic impacts of trade relations with foreign countries, particularly those affecting the United Kingdom.\n    \\item \\emph{BoE Expectations, Actions, Assets}: A sentence that discusses the Bank of England’s projections, policy actions, and changes in financial assets such as treasury bonds and bank reserves.\n    \\item \\emph{Money Supply}: A sentence that examines changes in the overall availability of money in the economy, including shifts in loan demand and monetary liquidity.\n    \\item \\emph{Key Words, Phrases}: A sentence that includes specific keywords or phrases which clearly indicate a particular monetary policy stance.\n    \\item \\emph{Labor}: A sentence that relates to shifts in labor market conditions, encompassing changes in productivity, wage trends, and job openings.\n\\end{itemize}\n\n\\paragraph{Examples: }\n\\begin{itemize}\n    \\item ``Recent economic indicators showing rising inflation and falling unemployment have led the Bank of England to signal a tighter monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: The BOE is concerned that overheating growth will fuel further inflation, prompting interest rate hikes.\n    \n    \\item ``The acceleration of house prices and energy costs is causing upward pressures on consumer demand, which may necessitate a proactive tightening of monetary policy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Hawkish}: Rising asset prices and energy costs are seen as signals of mounting inflationary pressures.\n    \n    \\item ``Falling inflation paired with a rise in unemployment has convinced policymakers at the Bank of England that a more accommodative stance is needed to support the economy.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: Lower inflation and softer labor market conditions suggest that further easing could help sustain economic growth.\n    \n    \\item ``Low money supply growth combined with persistently high loan demand has reinforced the BOE's outlook for maintaining an expansionary monetary policy stance.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Dovish}: These factors indicate subdued economic activity, reducing the likelihood of immediate monetary policy tightening.\n\n    \\item ``Total output prices had been flat year on year.''\\\\\n    \\textbf{Neutral}: The sentence states that total output prices remained stable and doesn't take a direction on monetary policy.\n    \n    \\item ``The new government had announced its intention to present an updated budget on 8 July.''\\\\\n
